questions.question: A 4-month-old infant presents developmental delay. MRI shows demyelination in the central nervous system. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what enzyme deficiency causes this condition? β -Galactosidase β -Glucosidase
questions.explanation: β -Galactosidase Correct Answer: B) Krabbe disease, β -Galactosidase Explanation: Krabbe disease occurs due to defects in β -Galactosidase, causing demyelination and mental retardation. Disease Enzyme deficiency Features Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A, Mental retardation Blindness Muscular weakness Cherry red spots in macula Fabry disease α -Galactosidase Skin rash(angiokeratoma) Kidney failure (full symptoms only in males - X-linked recessive) Krabbe disease (Option B) β -Galactosidase Mental retardation Near absence of myelin Predominant neurological manifestation and cranial nerves causing deafness and blindness. Gaucher disease (Option D ruled out) β -Glucosidase Enlarged liver and spleen Erosion of long bones Mental retardation in infants Anemia Thrombocytopenia Niemann-Pick disease (Option A ruled out) Sphingomyelinase Enlarged liver and spleen Mental retardation Fatal in early life Cherry red spot in macula Farber disease (Option C ruled out) Ceramidase Hoarseness Dermatitis Skeletal deformation Mental retardation Fatal in early life Reference: Harper 32nd edition page 245 Vasudevan 7th edition page 194

questions.question: Which enzyme in snake venom hydrolyzes only sn-2 acyl bond of phospholipids?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Phospholipase A2 Explanation: Phospholipase A2 acts on the 2nd carbon atom causing hydrolysis of the ester bond in phospholipids leading to cell membrane disruption and inflammation. Phospholipase A2: (Option A) Acts at the 2nd carbon atom. Hydrolysis of the ester bond in phospholipids Release of arachidonic acid. Causes cell membrane disruption. Phospholipase B (Option B) has both PLA1 and PLA2 activities. Hence, it can hydrolyze both the sn-1 and sn-2 acyl bonds of phospholipids. Phospholipase C (Option C) hydrolyzes the phosphodiester bond of phospholipids, particularly phosphatidylinositol. Phospholipase D (Option D) hydrolyzes the phosphodiester bond at the phosphate group. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3873700/

questions.question: Which of the following fatty acids is needed for humans from diet as humans cannot create double bonds beyond the 9th carbon from the carboxyl end of a fatty acid chain?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Alpha-linolenic acid Explanation: Alpha-linolenic acid is an essential fatty acid. It cannot be synthesized by the human body and must be obtained through the diet Essential fatty acids Non-essential fatty acids Cannot be synthesized by the human body and must be obtained through the diet. Humans cannot create double bonds beyond the 9th carbon atom from the carboxyl end of a fatty acid chain. Linoleic Acid (LA): An omega-6 fatty acid. Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) : An omega-3 fatty acid. (Option A) Can be synthesized by the human body from other dietary fats Palmitic acid (Option B ruled out) Oleic acid (Option C ruled out) Stearic acid (Option D ruled out) Reference: Harper 32nd edition page 232, 233

questions.question: Which of the following lipids is characterized by its amphipathic nature, allowing it to form micelles in aqueous solutions?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Phospholipids Explanation: Phospholipids are amphipathic lipids with both hydrophobic and hydrophilic properties. They have a polar head group (hydrophilic) and nonpolar tails (hydrophobic), enabling them to form micelles when in aqueous solutions. This property is crucial for various biological functions, including fat digestion and membrane formation. Lipids Categorized by Solubility: 1. Nonpolar Lipids: (Option D ruled out) Characteristics: Hydrophobic, insoluble in water, dominated by nonpolar hydrocarbon groups. Examples: Triacylglycerols (Triglycerides): Esters of glycerol with three fatty acid chains; primary fat storage in adipose tissue. (Option A ruled out) Cholesteryl Esters: Cholesterol esterified to a fatty acid; used for cholesterol storage and transport. (Option B ruled out) 2. Amphipathic Lipids: Characteristics: Both hydrophobic and hydrophilic; contain a polar head group and a nonpolar tail. Functions and Structures: Membranes: Bilayer structure with hydrophobic tails inward and hydrophilic heads outward Micelles: Spherical structures with hydrophobic tails in the center and hydrophilic heads on the surface; aid in fat digestion. Liposomes: Spherical vesicles with lipid bilayers enclosing an aqueous compartment Emulsions: Larger particles of nonpolar lipids dispersed in water, stabilized by amphipathic lipids; prevent coalescence. Examples: Phospholipids (Option C) Sphingolipids Cholesterol Reference: Harper 32nd edition page 205, 206, 209, 215, 264, 248, 259.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs correctly associates a disease with its corresponding enzyme deficiency? α -Galactosidase β -Glucosidase α -Galactosidase
questions.explanation: β -Glucosidase Correct Answer: B) Gaucher disease - β -Glucosidase Explanation: Gaucher disease is caused by a deficiency of β -Glucosidase, leading to the accumulation of glucosylceramide. Disease Enzyme Deficiency Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A Fabry disease α -Galactosidase Metachromatic leukodystrophy Arylsulfatase A Krabbe disease β -Galactocerebrosidase Gaucher disease β -Glucosidase Niemann-Pick disease types A, B Sphingomyelinase Farber disease Ceramidase Reference: Harper 32nd edition page 245

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy presents with episodic pain in his extremities, skin finding as shown in the image, and progressive renal dysfunction. A biopsy of the skin reveals the accumulation of ceramide trihexoside. An α -galactosidase deficiency is suspected. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Fabry disease Explanation: Fabry disease is due to a deficiency of α -galactosidase , leading to the accumulation of ceramide trihexoside , resulting in symptoms such as episodic pain, angiokeratomas (as shown in the image), and renal dysfunction. questions.question: A 6-month-old infant presents with a hoarse cry, painful and swollen joints, and skin nodules. The child also shows signs of developmental delay and mental retardation. Histological analysis reveals the accumulation of a certain substance in the tissues, which confirms the diagnosis of Farber disease. Which enzyme deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ceramidase Explanation: Farber disease is caused by a deficiency of ceramidase, leading to the accumulation of ceramide and presenting with a hoarse cry, painful and swollen joints, skin nodules, and mental retardation. Disease Enzyme Deficiency Lipid Accumulating Clinical Symptoms Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A, S (Option A ruled out) Cer—Glc—Gal(NeuAc) GalNAc GM2 Ganglioside Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness Fabry disease α -Galactosidase Cer—Glc—Gal—Gal Globotriaosylceramide Skin rash, kidney failure (symptoms manifest fully only in males; X-linked recessive) Metachromatic leukodystrophy Arylsulfatase A (Option B ruled out) Cer—Gal—OSO3 3-Sulfogalactosylceramide Mental retardation and psychological disturbances in adults; demyelination Krabbe disease β -Galactosidase Cer—Gal Galactosylceramide Mental retardation; myelin almost absent Gaucher disease β -Glucosidase Cer—Glc Glucosylceramide Enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, mental retardation in infants Niemann-Pick disease types A, B Sphingomyelinase (Option D ruled out) Cer—P—choline Sphingomyelin Enlarged liver and spleen, mental retardation; fatal in early life Farber disease Ceramidase (Option C) Acyl—Sphingosine Ceramide Hoarseness, dermatitis, skeletal deformation, mental retardation; fatal in early life Abbreviations: Cer, ceramide; Gal, galactose; Glc, glucose; NeuAc, N-acetylneuraminic acid; , site of deficient enzyme reaction. Reference: Harper 32nd edition page 245

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly, progressive neurodegeneration, and a history of frequent respiratory infections. A biopsy shows lipid-laden macrophages and a genetic test confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible for this condition? D. β -Glucosidase
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sphingomyelinase Explanation: Sphingomyelinase deficiency is responsible for Niemann-Pick disease types A and B, which present with hepatosplenomegaly, and neurodegeneration, biopsy shows lipid-laden macrophages (foam cells) and are often fatal in early life. Reference: Harper 32nd edition page 245

questions.question: A patient presents with bone pain, fatigue and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests reveal anemia and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages with a characteristic "wrinkled paper" appearance. Which substrate accumulates in Gaucher's disease due to the deficient enzyme activity?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Glucosylceramide Explanation: Gaucher's disease is characterized by the accumulation of glucosylceramide in RBCs and platelet membranes due to a deficiency in the enzyme beta-glucosidase , leading to anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages with a characteristic "wrinkled paper" appearance. Gaucher's disease: Lysosomal storage disease Defective enzyme: I -Glucosidase Defect in metabolism: Accumulation of cerebroside (Glucosylceramide) in RBCs and platelet membranes. (Option B) Pathophysiology: Abnormal RBCs and platelets are engulfed by macrophages leading to accumulation inside macrophages causing wrinkled paper appearance. Disease Enzyme deficiency Substance accumulation Features Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A, S Ganglioside (Option C) Mental retardation Blindness Muscular weakness Cherry red spots in macula Niemann-Pick disease Sphingomyelinase Sphingomyelin (Option A) Enlarged liver and spleen Mental retardation Fatal in early life Farber disease Ceramidase Ceramide (Option D) Hoarseness Dermatitis Skeletal deformation Mental retardation Fatal in early life

questions.question: Which of the following correctly matches the type of lipid with its description?

options.A: Fats - Liquid at room temperature, often containing polyunsaturated fatty acids.
options.B: Phospholipids - Contain glycerol and are the main lipid constituents of cell membranes.
options.C: Glycolipids - Esters of fatty acids that never contain sphingosine.

questions.explanation: membranes. Correct Answer: B) Phospholipids - Contain glycerol or sphingosine Explanation: Classification of lipids 1.Simple Lipids Esters of fatty acids with various alcohols. Further classified into fats, oils & waxes Fats Esters of fatty acids with glycerol; solid at room temperature. (Option A ruled out) Triacylglycerol with saturated fatty acids. Oils Fats in liquid state at room temperature. Triacylglycerols with polyunsaturated fatty acids. Waxes Esters of fatty acids with higher molecular weight monohydric alcohols. 2.Complex Lipids Esters of fatty acids with alcohol and other groups. Further classified based on additional groups present as Phospholipids, glycolipids and other complex lipids Phospholipids: Contain phosphoric acid; Main lipid constituents of membranes. (Option B) Glycerophospholipids Alcohol is glycerol. Phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylethanolamine. Sphingophospholipids Alcohol is sphingosine Sphingomyelin, found in myelin sheaths. Glycolipids: (glycosphingolipids) Contain fatty acid, sphingosine, and carbohydrate; Involved in cell adhesion and recognition (Option C ruled out) Cerebrosides (Option D ruled out) Galactosylceramide, a key component of myelin. Globosides Cell adhesion and Pathogen identification Gangliosides Highly concentrated in nerve tissues and function in cell-cell recognition, communication, and as receptors for hormones and bacterial toxins. Other Complex Lipids Includes sulfolipids, amino lipids, and lipoproteins. 3.Precursor/Derived Lipids Formed from hydrolysis of simple and complex lipids; Also act as precursors for lipid formation. Fatty acids, cholesterol, fatty aldehydes, ketone bodies, hydrocarbons, lipid-soluble vitamins, hormones. Reference: Harper’s biochemistry 32nd edition page 206,209,212

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant has developmental delay, muscle weakness, and on eye examination, a cherry-red spot on the macula is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which enzyme deficiency is responsible?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Tay-Sachs disease, Hexosaminidase A Explanation: In this scenario, the clinical features and fundoscopic image show cherry red spot in the macula are consistent with the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease. It is an inborn error of metabolism due to the failure of degradation of gangliosides, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A. Lipid Storage Diseases (Sphingolipidoses): They are a group of lysosomal storage diseases. Disease Enzyme deficiency Features Tay-Sachs disease (Option C) Hexosaminidase A Mental retardation Blindness Muscular weakness Cherry red spots in the macula Fabry disease α -Galactosidase Skin rash Kidney failure (full symptoms only in males X-linked recessive) Krabbe disease β -Galactosidase Mental retardation Near absence of myelin Predominant neurological manifestation and cranial nerves causing deafness and blindness. Gaucher disease (Option B ruled out) β -Glucosidase Enlarged liver and spleen Erosion of long bones Mental retardation in infants Anemia Thrombocytopenia Niemann-Pick disease (Option A ruled out)

questions.question: Which enzyme deficiency is responsible for GM1 gangliosidosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Beta-galactosidase Explanation: Beta-galactosidase removes galactose in GM 1 ganglioside and converts to GM 2 ganglioside . In the absence of the enzyme, it causes GM 1 gangliosidosis. Disease Enzyme deficiency Features Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A (Option D ruled out) Mental retardation Blindness Muscular weakness Cherry red spots in macula Fabry disease α -Galactosidase (Option C ruled out) Angiokeratomas (reddish purple spots) Kidney failure (full symptoms only in males X-linked recessive) GM1 gangliosidosis β -Galactosidase (Option B) Mental retardation Organomegaly Skeletal deformities Gaucher disease β -Glucosidase (Option A ruled out) Enlarged liver and spleen Erosion of long bones Mental retardation in infants Anemia Thrombocytopenia Niemann-Pick disease Sphingomyelinase Enlarged liver and spleen Mental retardation Fatal in early life Reference: Harper 32nd edition page 245

questions.question: Which component is present in gangliosides but not in cerebrosides or globosides?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) N-acetyl Neuraminic Acid Explanation: Gangliosides contain oligosaccharides as part of their structure, whereas cerebrosides contain only a single monosaccharide attached to ceramide. Ganglioside is a glycolipid, which is made of ceramide, oligosaccharide with NANA (N-acetyl Neuraminic Acid). Glycolipids: Also known as glycosphingolipids as alcohol in glycolipids are sphingosine. Glycosphingolipids are a combination of (Option B ruled out) ceramide with one or more sugar residues. Examples: cerebroside, globoside, and ganglioside. Glycolipids Composition Cerebroside Ceramide + monosaccharide (glucose or galactose) (Option A ruled out) Globoside Ceramide + oligosaccharide (glucose and galactose) Ganglioside Ceramide + oligosaccharide + NANA (N-acetyl Neuraminic Acid) (Option D) Ceramide: Ceramide is synthesised in the endoplasmic reticulum from the amino acid serine. Ceramide = Fatty acid (Option C ruled out) + Sphingosine Importance of glycosphingolipids: Constituents of plasma membranes Cell adhesion Cell recognition Signal transduction Some are antigens (ABO blood group substances) Reference: Harper 32nd edition page 243, 244

questions.question: Which of the following are the correct components of sphingomyelin?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ceramide + Phosphate + Choline Explanation: Sphingosine and fatty acids combine to form Ceramide . The phosphate group attaches to the free OH group in ceramide to create its derivative. Choline, when added to this derivative, forms Sphingomyelin Sphingomyelin is a type of lipid classified as a phospholipid and is an important component of cell membranes. Abundant in the myelin sheath that surrounds nerve fibers. Found in the outer leaflet of the cell membrane lipid bilayer and is a key component of lipid rafts. Plays an important role in cell signaling and apoptosis. Synthesis occurs primarily in the Golgi apparatus, Sphingosine + Fatty acid + Choline (Option A): This combination forms ceramide and choline but lacks the phosphate group , which is essential for sphingomyelin. Hence, incorrect. Sphingosine + Phosphate + Choline (Option C): Missing the fatty acid component that binds to sphingosine to form ceramide. So, it is incomplete. Incorrect. Ceramide + Phosphate + Fatty acids (Option D): Includes two fatty acids , which is incorrect. Only one fatty acid is present in ceramide; the head group should be choline , not another fatty acid. Reference: Harper 32nd edition page 210-211

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of four consecutive miscarriages over the past three years. After a thorough evaluation, a diagnosis is made . Which of the following phospholipids is specifically antigenic in this disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cardiolipin Explanation: The condition described is Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS), a disorder characterized by recurrent miscarriages, thrombosis, and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. Cardiolipin is a phospholipid that becomes antigenic in Antiphospholipid Syndrome, leading to the production of anti-cardiolipin antibodies. Other phospholipids (Phosphatidylserine, Phosphatidylinositol, Phosphatidylethanolamine) are not antigenic Phospholipids Location Function Synthesis Significance Phosphatidylserine (Option A ruled out) Inner leaflet of the plasma membrane Involved in apoptosis . It flips to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane, serving as a signal for phagocytes to engulf the dying cell. Synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) Plays a role in blood clotting by facilitating the binding of clotting factors. Supports neuronal function. Cardiolipin (Option C) inner mitochondrial membrane optimal function of numerous enzymes involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism. Stabilizes the respiratory chain complexes and supercomplexes Unique dimeric structure consisting of four fatty acid chains Synthesized in the mitochondria from phosphatidylglycerol and cytidine diphosphate-diacylglycerol (CDP-DAG) Antigenic Phosphatidylinositol (Option B ruled out) plasma membrane and intracellular membranes Involved in cell signaling pathways , particularly through the production of secondary messengers Plays a role in membrane trafficking and cytoskeletal organization. Produced in the ER and Golgi apparatus from CDP-DAG and inositol. Crucial for the function of insulin signaling and other receptor-mediated signal transduction pathways. Defects in phosphatidylinositol metabolism are linked to various diseases, including diabetes and cancer. Phosphatidylethanolamine (Option D ruled out) All cellular membranes Important for membrane fusion and the structural integrity of cellular membranes. Serves as a precursor for the synthesis of phosphatidylserine. Synthesized in the ER via the cytidine diphosphate-ethanolamine (CDP-ethanolamine) pathway or by decarboxylation of phosphatidylserine in the mitochondria. Plays a role in lipid metabolism and membrane dynamics. Deficiencies can impact cellular functions and are associated with various neurological disorders. Phosphatidylserine (Option A) is involved in cell signaling and apoptosis but is not antigenic. Phosphatidylinositol (Option B) is involved in cell signaling pathways and membrane dynamics but is not antigenic. Phosphatidylethanolamine (Option D) is a common phospholipid in cell membranes but is not antigenic. Reference: Harper 32nd edition page 240, 241 Lippincott Illustrated reviews 7th edition 592-599

questions.question: What compound is formed when choline is added to the following structure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Lecithin Explanation: This structure is called phosphatidate — phosphatide when combined with choline results in the formation of Phosphatidylcholine also known as Lecithin . Formation of Phosphotidate: When the first two OH groups of a glycerol molecule are esterified with fatty acids. And the third OH group bonds with a phosphate group This combination forms phosphatidate , which is a precursor to all glycerophospholipids. Lecithin: In phosphatidylcholine, if the first two fatty acids are palmitic acid, the compound is known as Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline . This substance is a key component of pulmonary surfactant. It is synthesized by type 2 pneumocytes in the lungs. In the later stages of the third trimester, it is produced by fully developed fetal lungs. Premature neonates often lack this surfactant due to the underdevelopment of their lungs. Phospholipids: Phospholipid Composition Lecithin (Option A) Free phosphate + choline Phosphatidylserine Free phosphate + Serine Phosphatidylinositol Free phosphate + Inositol (Option D ruled out) Cephalin (Option B ruled

questions.question: A premature baby presents with infant respiratory distress syndrome. The neonatologist says the neonate is yet to produce a type of phospholipid adequately. All of the following belong to the same class except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Cerebrosides Explanation: The neonate in respiratory distress syndrome fails to produce Lecithin ( phosphatidylcholine ), a phospholipid crucial for surfactant production. Cephalin, Cardiolipin, and Lecithin are all phospholipids. Cerebroside is a glycolipid and not a phospholipid. Classification of Phospholipids(esters containing phosphate groups with fatty acid and alcohol.) Glycerophospholipids Alcohol: Glycerol Phosphatidylcholine (Lecithin) (Option C ruled out) Most abundant in cell membranes, major source of choline. Phosphatidylethanolamine (Cephalin) (Option A ruled out) Found in membranes; differs from phosphatidylcholine by choline substitution. Phosphatidylserine Similar to phosphatidylethanolamine; found in cell membranes. Phosphatidylinositol Contains myoinositol. Cardiolipin (Option B ruled out) Found in mitochondria; synthesized from phosphatidylglycerol. Lysophospholipids Contains one acyl radical; e.g., lysophosphatidylcholine (lysolecithin). Plasmalogens 10–30% of phospholipids in brain/heart; ether link instead of ester. Sphingophospholipids Alcohol: Sphingosine Sphingomyelins Found in myelin sheaths and cell membrane lipid rafts. Reference: Harper’s biochemistry 32nd edition page 209- 210
